Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that the Applicant failed to meet residency requirements under subsection 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 171 days during the four-year period preceding the application
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to alleged failure to meet 1,095-day physical residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Alleged failure to meet physical residency requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate reasoning by Citizenship Judge regarding residency calculation
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal brought under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Basis: Failure to meet statutory physical residency requirement
Evidence_Assessed: Absence records, ICES and OHIP reports
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or remittal for new hearing
Governing_Rule: Applicants must physically reside in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not explain calculation of absences or address all submitted evidence
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remanded for new hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to insufficiently reasoned decision
Cause_Description: Applicant's citizenship application was denied due to alleged non-compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient analysis and explanation of ICES and OHIP evidence by the Judge
Evidence_Issues: Lack of transparency and intelligibility in how evidence was assessed
Residency_Compliance: Not met, as per Judgeâ€™s unreasoned conclusion
Decision_Rationale: The decision lacked justification, transparency, and intelligibility, rendering it unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to account for or explain use of key documentary evidence
